Chapter 7: Refuting the Characteristics of the Conditioned, Part 7. Next, having separately analyzed the faculties, objects, and non-self, we will now comprehensively discuss the emptiness of the characteristics of the conditioned.
Namely, the conditioned dharmas such as form and mind are endowed with the three characteristics of arising, abiding, and ceasing. Because arising is foremost, we will first refute arising.
Once the characteristic of arising is gone, abiding and ceasing will be eliminated accordingly.
Some say that the essence of the effect originally does not exist but arises.
In order to refute this statement, a verse is spoken:
If it originally does not exist but arises, why does it not arise before?
The treatise says:
When the various causes such as seeds reach the state of transformation and destruction, they can attract the various effects such as sprouts and cause them to arise.
If the various effects originally do not exist within the various causes, why do the sprouts, etc. only arise at this stage?
In the later stage, the prior effect should not arise. In the prior stage, the later effect should also arise.
Moreover, this effect should arise from that cause, or that cause should arise from this effect.
If this and that cause do not arise without this and that effect, the power of this and that cause should also not arise, because they are the same as the original non-existence.
If so, all causes and effects are non-existent, which contradicts one's own school's doctrine of causes and effects.
Some say that the substance of the effect originally exists and arises.
In order to refute this, another verse is spoken:
That which originally exists and arises should arise again later.
The treatise says:
If all effects originally exist in the causes, why do sprouts and so forth not arise again later?
In the later stage, the effect should arise again as it does now;
In the present stage, the effect should not arise as it will in the future.
Moreover, if the effect originally has a substance in the cause, why is it said to arise in this stage?
If you say it is now manifested, then manifestation is not separate from substance and should not have been non-existent originally. Now, as before, it should also not be manifested.

If it is the same as this state, manifestation should not be non-existent. If manifestation is not non-existent originally and is manifested again now, then later it should be manifested again. This would be an infinite regress.
Original existence contradicts the meaning of arising. If you say the effect exists originally, arising will definitely not be accomplished.
Since there is no arising, the meaning of the effect is lost.
Since the meaning of the effect is lost, there is no cause, which contradicts your own doctrine that there is a meaning of cause and effect.
Next, the one who says the effect exists before the cause makes this statement:
The effect may contradict the cause, so they do not exist simultaneously.
This statement is unreasonable, so the next verse says:
If the effect can contradict the cause, it should not be non-existent before.
The treatise says:
The SÄá¹ƒkhyas say that the effect may contradict the cause or not contradict the cause.
The effect that contradicts the cause is the effect of conjunction, which arises after the conjunction, because the previous action has ceased.
Moreover, contradictory dharmas are of two kinds:

The first is that which obstructs, and the second is that which destroys. The latter refers to the cause of the destruction of the combined virtues, while the former refers to the combined virtues that obstruct heaviness, etc., preventing the arising of the action of falling, etc.
In this way, if the combined virtues do not yet exist, they should not be able to contradict the previously arisen action.
The world has not seen that that which lacks substance can contradict. You should not say that the combined virtues and action are like a prisoner and an executioner.
They are mutually contradictory. Do not contradict your own tenet that cause and effect do not occur simultaneously.
If you allow that action occurs simultaneously with the combination, then it should be so afterwards as well, because there is no difference.
Then it would contradict your own treatise and what is commonly known in the world. Therefore, you should not say that the effect does not exist prior to it.
Next, the proponents of the prior existence of the effect say:
The substance of the effect exists prior to all causes.
This is also unreasonable. Therefore, the next verse says:
If the effect is established, the cause has no use. Prior existence is also not established.
The treatise states:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
The SÄá¹ƒkhyas say:
The substance of the effect exists prior to all causes.
This is also not so.
Because the arising and manifestation of the effect are called causes.
The substance of the effect has originally already arisen and already manifested:
The cause then has no use.
Why is this?
Because the substance and manifestation are inseparable, it should be like its substance, originally not non-existent.

The meaning of the cause of the originally existing manifestation does not exist. Because the cause does not exist, the meaning of the effect is not established. It contradicts one's own school's establishment of the existence of cause and effect.
Furthermore, because the meaning of the arising of dharmas is not established, one should not definitely grasp that dharmas have arising.
Why is this?
Therefore the next verse says:
At this time there is no arising, and at that time there is also no arising;
At this time and that time there is no arising, at what time will there be arising?
The treatise says:
When the effect already exists, because its substance exists, it should not be called arising, like a dharma that originally exists.

Because the future effect does not yet exist, it is like a definitely nonexistent dharma and is not called arising.ğŸ”½Moreover, the arising of the functioning of dharmas is called arising. Since its substance does not yet exist, on what can its functioning be based?
Also, it is called a cause because it gives rise to an effect. Since the substance of the effect does not yet exist, what does the cause give rise to?
Since there is nothing to give rise to, the meaning of cause is not established.
If the meaning of cause does not exist, from what does the effect arise?
Apart from these two states, there is no other time of arising. Therefore arising definitely does not exist, like space and so forth.
Moreover, if you maintain that the substance of dharmas definitely exists, it is not called arising, because there is nothing to give rise to.
Although its functioning arises, it is in the future, and because it does not yet exist, it is not arising.
It already exists in the present, but this is not accepted by our own school.
Apart from these two states, there is no other time of arising. Therefore arising definitely does not exist.

Or, the SÄá¹ƒkhyas hold that many real things are causes, and the effect, a unitary quality, is produced by their aggregation. When the many conditions are not yet complete, the quality of aggregation does not yet exist. For this reason, it is said that at that time there is no production.
When the many conditions are complete, the quality of aggregation already exists. For this reason, it is said that at that time there is no production.
Because when the aggregation first occurs, the substance of the aggregation already exists, it should be like the subsequent stage and not be called production.
Because what has already been produced in the subsequent stage is not produced again, it can be called non-production.
But the initial stage is not like this, so what fault is there in calling it production?
If it is not produced later, the effect should contradict the real.

But you do not allow that the effect contradicts the real, or that obstruction contradicts destruction. The quality of aggregation contradicts action but does not contradict the real. This has already been briefly explained above.
Apart from this, there is no other stage at that time. Therefore, the quality of aggregation definitely has no production.

In the same way, form and so forth depend on real causes. When the real has not yet existed, the substance of the effect has not yet existed. For this reason, it is said that at that time there is no production.
When the effect already exists, the substance of the effect already exists, and therefore it is said that at that time it does not arise.
Because when the effect first exists, form, etc. already exist, and therefore it should not be said to arise, just as it does not in a later stage.
Apart from that time, there is no other stage, and therefore form, etc. definitely do not arise.

In the same way, when the substance of the obstacle to the union of merit, etc. and the action of falling, etc. does not yet exist, the action does not arise. This should be explained in the same way as above.
Apart from existence and nonexistence, there is no other stage, and therefore the action of falling, etc. definitely does not arise.
Or, the SÄá¹ƒkhyas hold that milk, etc. transform into curd, etc., and therefore it is said that they arise.
When the substance of the cause exists, the nature of the cause has not yet transformed, and therefore it is said that at that time it does not arise.
If at that time the nature of the cause has already transformed, then it loses the nature of the cause and should not be called a cause.
When the substance of the effect exists, the cause immediately becomes the effect, and therefore it is said that at that time it does not arise.
If at that time the nature of the effect arises, it should be the arising of a different dharma, not the completion of the cause itself.
Apart from this, at that time there is no other state. Therefore curd and so forth definitely have no arising.
The causes such as self-nature complete the effects such as earth, etc. According to this investigation, they all have no arising.
Furthermore, because the produced does not exist, the meaning of arising is not established.
Why is this?
Therefore the next verse says:
Just as arising does not exist for self-nature,
so it is also for other natures. How can the meaning of arising be established as existent?
The treatise says:

The school that advocates eternal existence says that the five aggregates such as form, the non-Buddhist path of SÄá¹ƒkhya says that the three qualities such as pleasure, because when dharmas arise they do not cause self-nature to change, the meaning of arising is not established.
Because when dharmas have not yet arisen, all the functions of arising do not yet exist, the meaning of arising is not established.
Because when dharmas arise, they do not cause other natures to change, the meaning of arising is not established.
Because when dharmas are born, the function of all birth has already ceased, and therefore the meaning of birth is not established.

It cannot be said that the characteristics and functions of form, etc., and pleasure, etc., change and are therefore called birth, because at the moment of birth, if the nature is the same as the characteristics and functions, or different from them, there are errors and contradictions with our own tenets.

It also cannot be said that the intrinsic nature of form, etc., and pleasure, etc., changes and is therefore called birth, lest at the moment of birth, form, etc., and pleasure, etc., change and become the intrinsic nature of feeling, etc., and suffering, etc.
Some say:
Because the theory of prior existence of the effect has the error mentioned above, the meaning of birth may be nonexistent;
but if the effect does not exist prior to the conditions, when the substance of the effect is about to be formed through the combination of causes and conditions, the meaning of birth should exist.
When the effect is about to be formed, its substance does not yet exist. How can it be said that the effect arises from conditions?
We know that the cause has the ability to form the substance of the effect, just as it is said that the effect is born because rice is cooked.
If that is so, the name birth should be conventional and not real, because at the moment of the birth of form, etc., it does not yet exist.
This hypothetical explanation is also not contradictory, because when it is born, it is not seen later.
If this is so, then the stage of being seen can be called birth, because when it is seen, it is said to be born. How can you ask about the principle that is not understood?
Although it is said to be born at the time of seeing, it is not born at the time of seeing. It is said to be born because of seeing, not because of birth. Why is there no seeing at the time of birth?
Because of the absence of seeing, it is known that there is no birth at the time of birth.
How can you answer without understanding the principle?
Isn't it that the absence of seeing is called the absence of seeing? Why do you answer with a question?
If this is so, then there should be an infinite regress of questions and answers, because the absence of seeing seeing the absence is said to be endless.

Moreover, it cannot be said that there is birth for the unconditioned, because it is like a flower in the sky and contradicts the principle of birth. Even when it reaches the present, it is not called birth.
Because it is like the unconditioned and contradicts the principle of birth, and because what is born does not exist, the meaning of birth is not established.
Next, those who hold the view of existence say:
The effect has three times, with distinctions of before and after, when it is about to arise and function, and when it is finally completed.
To show that they are not established, the next verse says:
In the first, middle, and last stages, arising is definitely not established before.
The treatise says:

If the effect is prior to the cause, when it has not yet arisen, the three stages are not established, because there is no distinction between existence and nonexistence. The first, middle, and last stages are manifested based on existence, but when it has not yet arisen, the essence does not exist, so how can it be established?
Or it should be allowed that the effect is not nonexistent before it arises, because seeing those three stages is only based on existence.

If the effect exists prior to the cause, when it has not yet arisen, the three stages are not established, because there is a distinction between existence and nonexistence. The essence exists but is not distinguished, and the characteristics and functions have not yet arisen, so how can it be said that the three stages have differences?
Moreover, since these three stages are not simultaneous, arising is also not established.
Therefore, the next verse says:
Since two twos are already nonexistent, how can one one exist?
The treatise says:
The prior, middle, and later stages are established in relation to each other. Since the two-by-two [stages] do not exist, how could the one-by-one [stages] exist?
It cannot be said that the three stages occur simultaneously, because the names prior, middle, and later are established based on time.
Moreover, it cannot be said that the three stages exist simultaneously, lest there be the fault of the confusion of these three [stages].
You also do not allow the three stages to occur simultaneously, so one time [stage] definitely does not have the three [stages].

If it is said that the discerning wisdom observes the two-by-two [stages] of form and other dharmas and establishes each stage, then the three stages are only nominally existent and not truly existent, contradicting your teacher's tenet that the three stages truly exist.
Therefore, the three stages are only nominally existent and not truly existent. One should not definitely grasp that the effect has three stages.
Furthermore, form and other dharmas definitely have no arising, because the causes and conditions that give rise to them are not established.
Arising definitely comes from self, from other, or from the combination of the two.
All three are impossible. In order to illustrate this meaning, a verse is spoken:
Not apart from other natures, only arising from self-nature;
Not from other or both, therefore arising definitely does not exist.
The treatise says:
Because it is not logically possible for one dharma at one time to be its own cause and effect, it does not arise from itself.
If within one essence there are two distinct aspects called cause and effect, one's own meaning is not established.
One's own words deny others, revealing one's own characteristics. How can it be called self-arising if the effect arises from the cause?

Moreover, the essence should not be established as one, just as the characteristics. The characteristics should not be established as two, just as their essence. Therefore, the statement that one essence with two characteristics is called cause and effect is definitely not logically possible.
Moreover, the word self-arising arises based on meaning, not based on meaning. That which does not arise from meaning is not self-arising.
Not arising from meaning, it is the same as an echo from a tree. How can it definitely express the self-arising of all dharmas?
Moreover, the word self-arising arises based on wisdom, not based on wisdom. That which does not arise based on wisdom arises from others.
If it does not arise in dependence on wisdom, it should be the same as the words of a madman or a drunkard, difficult to believe and rely on.
Moreover, if one says it arises by itself and gives rise to understanding in others, if it does not give rise to understanding in others, one loses one's own position.
If understanding does not arise in others, speaking is of no benefit. On what basis would one forcefully establish the doctrine of self-arising?
It is clearly seen in the world that dharmas arise from conditions. The doctrine of self-arising contradicts this.
Moreover, if it arises by itself, it should contradict worldly dharmas. A knife does not cut itself, a needle does not sew itself.

Moreover, the doctrine of self-arising depends on you for arising. If it does not depend on you for arising, it is not called self-arising. If it does not depend on you for arising, it should not be your doctrine.
Alas, the ignorant are confused and do not understand their own words.
Moreover, the doctrine of self-arising is the same as the doctrine of no cause, denying all causes and conditions for arising results.
Some say:
It does not give rise to itself, because at the time of arising it does not yet exist, like a past dharma that has ceased.
If it is said that at the time of arising its substance already exists, it should be the same as the present, and the function of arising would be useless.
It is also unreasonable to say that the essence of a dharma is manifested and called arising.
If manifestation and essence are different, then the dharma loses its self-nature.
If manifestation and essence are the same, then manifestation should originally exist.
If manifestation originally exists, then the function of arising should be nonexistent.
Therefore, the statement of self-arising definitely does not accord with reason.
The statement that a dharma arises from another is also unreasonable.
When a dharma arises, its own essence does not yet exist. Since there is no self, how can there be another to be called?
The causes and conditions are called another in relation to their own effects. Since the own effects do not yet exist, the meaning of another is not established.
If it is said that when arising, the own effect already exists, then the causes and conditions are useless.
It is not said that another generates it, because it is manifested and called arising.
This is also unreasonable.
If manifestation is not separate from the essence, it should originally not be nonexistent.
Moreover, the cause is called another in relation to the effect, because the effect is different from the cause. The effect should also be called another.
If both cause and effect are others, then there is no self.
Since the self does not exist, the other should also be nonexistent. The statement of arising from another has no meaning.

Also, when the effect is viewed by wisdom, the cause is said to be other. Cause and effect certainly do not exist simultaneously.ğŸ”½When the cause exists, the effect does not yet exist. What is born from another?
When the effect exists, the cause no longer exists. From what other does it arise?
Isn't it the case that when wisdom views the later and observes the earlier, it is said to be born from another, and there is no error in this?
That is to say, when observing the future effect or recollecting past causes, cause and effect are both established, just like father and son. This may be so in name, but not in reality.
Cause and effect are at different times and do not exist simultaneously. How can one insist that they are really born from another?
The expression like father and son is also unreasonable.
In the world, father and son often exist at the same time. Even if only one exists, it can still be metaphorically referred to as the other.
Cause and effect are not like this. How can the metaphor be the same?

If it is said that at an earlier time, with regard to a thing with a different nature, wisdom observes and grasps its different characteristics, and then with regard to cause and effect, the later is viewed as the earlier, and the distinctions of self and other are established,

When the subsequent speech occurs, it does not touch the previous two, but merely speaks according to thought. The dharma arises from others, so the dharma and the analogy are the same, without the previous fault.
This defense is unreasonable.
Why is this?
Different things occurring simultaneously have no causal meaning. Cause and effect must not occur at the same time.
Father and son are not like this. How can they be used as an analogy?
Moreover, if it is said that this meaning is not nonexistent, but you grasp it as real, therefore it is unreasonable.
If it is said, Why chew on empty space?
It is presently seen that causes and conditions can give rise to effects. The characteristics of the effect are different from them, and they are said to be other.
Why bother with complicated words to firmly question the characteristics?
According to one's wishes, do not say it is other or not other. There must be a distinction between what can give rise and what is given rise to. This is enough to bring joy. Why rely on many words?

It is said to arise according to desire, without the need for exhaustive investigation. Indulge in your constant joy and thoroughly engage in mutual negation, because worry and joy arise from the deluded thoughts of one's own mind.
You say there must be a producer and something produced. Whether you say they are provisional or real, you must answer.
If you say they are provisional, you contradict your own doctrine. If you say they are real, what fault is there in questioning it? If what is produced does not yet exist, what produces it?
If what produces it does not yet exist, what is produced?
Therefore, in terms of the highest truth, arising from another is not established. Relying on conventional discourse, mere words are of no benefit.
The reason for engaging in debate is due to differences in views. The whole world knows this. Why bother with general talk? Therefore, one should not insist on arising from another.
Arising from self, other, or both is also unreasonable, as the previous two faults accumulate in your doctrine.
Since the individual is not established, how can the general be established?
Therefore, all dharmas are definitely unproduced, because arising from self, other, or both is unreasonable.
Furthermore, the producer and what is produced, whether simultaneous or sequential, are both unreasonable, therefore they definitely do not arise.
Why is this?
Therefore, the next verse says:
Before, after, and at the same time, both are not to be spoken of;
Therefore, arising and pots, etc., are only nominally existent, not truly existent.
The treatise says:
If the produced dharma is prior to the producer, apart from the producer, what is there to be produced?
This produced dharma, even if apart from the producer, then the producer would be useless.
If the produced dharma is after the producer, without a basis, how can there be a producer?
Even if apart from the produced, what use is the producer?
Moreover, if these two dharmas are not simultaneous, what can the able one be able to?
What can the receptive one be receptive to?

If the produced dharma is simultaneous with the producer, since they arise at the same time, they should not depend on each other, like the two horns of an ox, which do not rely on each other, there should be no distinction between the producer and the produced.
When the produced does not yet exist, the producer also does not exist. When the produced exists, what use is the producer?

These two dharmas, whether before or after, simultaneously or not, are both unreasonable. Therefore, arising does not exist. Following worldly convention, we say there is that which gives rise and that which is given rise to, but this cannot be investigated and analyzed in terms of the same or different time periods.
Furthermore, the view that effects have arising must be based on old and new. Since old and new do not exist, arising cannot be established.
Because the two are both not the self-characteristics of dharmas, mutually contradicting, they must not be simultaneous.
Even if one allows them to be simultaneous, they should exist apart from dharmas.
If they exist apart from dharmas, who is old and who is new?
You should not say that the characteristics of different substances are manifested, because we presently see that apart from dharmas there is no old and no new.
Nor should you say that the same substance simultaneously exists, because they mutually contradict each other, just as good and evil minds are not simultaneous.
Therefore, the next verse says:
If the old is before the new, prior arising would not make sense.
If the old is after the new, subsequent arising would not be established.
The treatise says:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

We see in the world that the later is new and the earlier is old. You should not be so obstinate as to insist that the earlier is new and the later is old.ğŸ”½It is necessary that the later be new and the earlier become old. If the old existed earlier, the new would be nonexistent.
Because the new is called later and the old is called earlier, if the new is nonexistent, the old would also be nonexistent.
Since the new and old are both nonexistent, what is there that can be said to be born?
It is also unreasonable to say that the old exists after the new.
When the new arises, the old does not yet exist, because the substance is not yet differentiated. Later it also should not exist.
If you say that the old substance arises separately later, then when the new arises, how can you say that the old is born?
If you say that the infant born later, whose body is red and has not yet changed, is old, this is definitely unreasonable.
If you say that when a dharma first arises, it is old, then all dharmas would be absolutely without newness.
Since the new is nonexistent, the old also does not exist, because the old must be preceded by the new.
If you say that dharmas are born moment by moment and are always called new and never old, then if the old does not exist, the new also should not exist.
If you distinguish the old and call it new, since the old does not exist, what is there to distinguish?
Since there is nothing to distinguish, the distinguisher also does not exist. Therefore you should not insist that there is new and old.
Since there is neither new nor old, how can birth be established?

However, in the world, we see conditioned dharmas arising in similar continuity and call them a single substance. We say they are new and old, with flourishing in the beginning and decline in the end.
The holy ones speak in accordance with this, saying there is old and new. This is established based on the conventional, not the real.
Furthermore, if the substance of a result is born, it must be born based on the substance of causes in the past, future, and present.
However, all are not established. Therefore the next verse says:
The present does not arise from present causes, nor from past or future causes.
The future also does not arise from past, future, or present causes.
The treatise says:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Present dharmas are not born from present causes, because it is not reasonable for cause and effect to exist simultaneously.
Although form, shadow, etc., are simultaneous as cause and effect, they are conventionally said to be not real but nominal, following worldly convention.
The two time periods of past and future are already extinguished or not yet born, and their substance and characteristics do not exist. Causes and functions do not exist.
Moreover, the substance and characteristics of present dharmas are already established. How could they rely on the three time periods of causes to arise?
Future dharmas do not rely on past and future as causes, because that which is already extinguished or not yet born has no causal function.
Isn't it that when the present is about to be extinguished, its substance serves as a cause to give rise to future effects?
How can future effects, which have no substance, give rise to anything?

If you say that when future effects are born they have substance, they should be called present, so how can you call them future? You should not say that birth is the same as having substance, nor can you say that having substance is the same as birth.
If having substance is the same as birth, birth should be present;
if birth is the same as having substance, having substance should be future.
If having substance is in the future, the future should be present;
If it exists in the present, the present should be the future.

This contradicts your doctrine that the characteristics of time are fixed, and also contradicts your own statement that birth exists in the future. Therefore, it cannot be said that the present, about to cease, acts as a cause to give rise to the future effect. Because there is a fault whether or not the effect exists at the time of the cause.
Furthermore, some say:

The future has a complete substance and characteristics. Based on this, the function of birth has a basis. Birth moves the future and causes it to enter the present. Cessation moves the present and causes it to enter the past.
In order to refute this statement, a verse is spoken:
If it is complete, it does not come. If it has ceased, it should not go.
The treatise says:
Just as the present has a complete substance and characteristics, the future should not come and enter the present.
Or, because the future is not the present, etc., its substance and characteristics are not complete, just like empty flowers.
Moreover, because the future is not the present, like the past, it does not enter the present.
If the future has a real nature, it should have no function of arising, just as the present does not.
Or else, the function of arising in the future should be nonexistent, because it is not present, just as the past is not.
Although dharmas such as form exist in the present, they are also said to be perishing, because they will certainly perish.
This present dharma does not go to the past, because its time is definitely different, just as the future is.
Also, the present dharma should be like the past and not go to the past, because it is not future.
Also, the past time is not gone to by the present, because it is included in time, just like the future, etc.
The present is also not entered by the future, because it is included in time, just like the future.
Because the past and future are not present, etc., they should be like the horns of a rabbit, both lacking a real nature.
If the future lacks a real nature, what does arising depend on for existence?

Therefore, one should not grasp that form and other effects arise. Since arising is non-existent, cessation also does not exist. But following convention, one speaks of cessation and arising, which exist like illusions and so forth.
In order to illustrate this meaning, another verse is spoken:
The characteristics of the essence of dharmas are like this, the analogies of illusions and so forth are not false.
The treatise states:
The beginning and end of form and other dharmas do not exist. The present does not remain long, just like illusions and so forth.
Moreover, if form and other dharmas arise from conditions, like what is created by illusions, they all do not truly exist.
That which is not produced from conditions is all like empty flowers, with both nature and characteristics empty. One should not say they exist.

Since dharmas do not exist, arising and so forth definitely do not exist. How can one say that arising moves the future and causes it to enter the present, and that cessation moves the present and causes it to enter the past?
Furthermore, the characteristics of arising, abiding, and ceasing, whether before or after, simultaneously or not, are all unreasonable and should not be grasped.
Why is this?
Therefore, the next verse says:
The three characteristics of arising, abiding, and ceasing, if simultaneous, cannot exist,
If sequential, they also do not exist. How can you grasp them as existent?
The treatise says:
If a single substance has many characteristics simultaneously, mutually contradicting each other, the principle must be incomplete.
If you grasp them as simultaneous, the substance should be different. Since you grasp them as the same substance, they cannot be simultaneous.
Grasping them as not simultaneous is also unreasonable. How can the different characteristics exist at different times if the substance to be characterized is the same?

When the substance of a dharma arises, abiding and ceasing do not yet exist. When it reaches the state of abiding and ceasing, the characteristic of arising has already ceased. To say that the substance is the same is extremely deluded and mistaken.
If you say that the characteristics are different before and after, but the substance is the same, then the substance of wholesome, unwholesome, form, and mind should be the same.

However, when abandoning the previous characteristics and the subsequent characteristics arise, the substance and the characteristics are the same. There should be abandonment and attainment. How can you grasp them as the same substance before and after?
The three substances being different is also unreasonable.
Since arising, abiding, and ceasing are found in all conditioned dharmas, how can the three natures each have only one characteristic?
It is also unreasonable to maintain that they each have only one characteristic.

The nature of ceasing is without arising and should not be produced by causes. The nature of arising is without ceasing and should be eternal by nature. Abiding is without ceasing and arising and should not be included in the aggregates. If you admit that each has three characteristics, there is the above error, or else there is an infinite regress.
The three characteristics cannot be simultaneous or sequential. Since there is no other alternative, how can you maintain that they exist?

Furthermore, if arising, etc., exist separately from the characterized, they should have the characteristics of arising, etc., just as form, etc., do, and then the characteristics of arising, etc., should not be different substances.
Why is this?
Therefore the next verse says,ğŸ”½If the characteristics of arising, etc.,
Have further characteristics of arising, etc.,
Abiding and ceasing should be like arising, or arising and abiding should be like ceasing.
The treatise says:

If the characteristics of birth, etc., exist simultaneously with their support, just as the support has birth, etc., that are separate from it, then since the characteristics of birth, etc., are the same in form as their support, how can they be different from each other?

If you say that birth, etc., are like such dharmas as form, which, although existing simultaneously with birth, etc., are different from them, and the characteristics of obstruction, etc., are different from each other, then difference of substance is possible.
But the characteristics of birth, etc., are the same, so how can their substance be different?

Since the functions of birth, etc., are different, they must be different in substance, just as form, etc., are. This reason is not conclusive, because, like the eye and other organs, although their functions are many, their substances are one. Therefore the difference in functions cannot be used as an example.

The functions of the eye, etc., are different, but their time is the same, so their substances are one. The functions of birth, etc., are different, and their time is different, so their substances are many. Why does the time of the function of birth, etc., differ?
Their own substance exists simultaneously and does not depend on a different time. How can their functions differ in time?
Since the two characteristics of continuance and cessation are initially without function, they must be so subsequently, because their substance is no different.
Or else, arising, etc., are the same as dharmas, because they have arising, etc., in common, and therefore they should be similar to each other.
Each has the function of the other, or each lacks its own function. Therefore arising, etc., should not exist separately.
Next, are the characteristics of arising, etc., of dharmas such as form different from them?
Or are they not different?
They are not different, and therefore the next verse says:
If the characterized is different from the characteristics, why is its substance not permanent?
The treatise says:

If dharmas such as form are different from arising, etc., they should be without arising and ceasing, like cessation through discrimination, etc. They should not be observed as all impermanent. Observing them as impermanent would constitute a mistaken view.

If it is said that form, etc., combine with arising, etc., although they are observed as impermanent, it is not a mistaken view, just as a person is called a stick or a horn because of combining with a stick or a horn, this is not so, because they are different from arising, etc.
They should be like unconditioned dharmas, not combining with arising, etc.

If the substance and characteristics of arising, etc., of form, etc., were different, how could one observe them with a single mind and wisdom, thinking the arising, abiding, and ceasing of form, etc.?
Therefore, the dharmas of form, etc., are not different from arising, etc.
They are also not non-different. Therefore, the next verse says:
If non-different, the four should be the same, or else they would be completely non-existent.
The treatise says:

If the dharmas of form, etc., were not different from arising, etc., they should be divisible like arising, etc., into three. Arising, etc., should also be mixed into one, because they are not different in substance from the dharmas of form, etc.
Or the characteristics of arising, etc., would each lose their own substance, because they are not different in substance from abiding, etc.
Form, etc., would also lose their own substance, because they are the same in substance as arising, etc.

Then there would be no characterized form, etc., because the characterized does not exist. Because of the non-existence of the characterized, the characteristics would also not exist, and then there would be no conditioned [dharmas].
Unconditioned [dharmas] would also be the same, because they are established in relation to each other. Everything would be non-existent.
Therefore, the dharmas of form, etc., are not different from arising, etc.
Furthermore, cause and effect, whether existent or non-existent, cannot be established, and the arising dependent on them also cannot be accomplished.
Why is this?
Therefore, the next verse says:
There is no existent dharma that arises, nor is there an existent dharma that does not arise;
There is no non-existent dharma that arises, nor is there a non-existent dharma that does not arise.
The treatise says:

The meaning of an existent dharma arising cannot be established, because arising and existence are simultaneous and mutually contradictory.ğŸ”½An existent dharma without arising also cannot be established, because it is like an already ceased non-existence, which is not what arises.
A non-existent dharma with arising cannot be established in principle, because it is like an unarisen non-existence, which is not able to give rise to anything.
A non-existent dharma without arising also cannot be established, because it is like the first two non-existences, which are not cause and effect.
Or, the two non-existences cannot be cause and effect, because they are like an absolute non-existence, which is not cause and effect.
In this way, the different entities of cause and effect have already been refuted.
In order to refute the same entity, another verse is spoken:
The existence of an existent dharma is not established, nor is the existence of a nonexistent dharma;
The nonexistence of an existent dharma is not established, nor is the nonexistence of a nonexistent dharma.
The treatise says:
The existence of an existent dharma is not logically established.
Because an existent dharma has already been established, establishment is useless.
If establishment were to establish again, establishment would be endless.
If establishment were different from the characteristic, its substance would necessarily be separate.
It is definitely not the case that a different characteristic and the same substance are logical, because the characteristic and its substance are inseparable.
The logic of the existence of a nonexistent dharma is also not established, because its characteristic is different, like suffering and pleasure, etc.

Or else, existence and nonexistence should be without distinction, because the substance of existence and nonexistence is the same, which contradicts reason.ğŸ”½The meaning of the nonexistence of an existent dharma is not established, because it commits the same errors as the existence of a nonexistent dharma.
The meaning of the nonexistence of a nonexistent dharma is also not established, because it commits the same errors as the existence and nonexistence of a characteristic.

Or, if it is said that there is no arising, this is the self-nature grasped by the SÄá¹ƒkhyas, which does not depend on others to be established. Although there is hidden ability, there is no manifest substance. It is said to be non-existent based on what they grasp.
Thus, existence, non-existence, cause, effect, sameness, and difference are all not established, so there definitely is no arising.
Furthermore, arising has already ceased and has not yet been obtained, so both the arisen and the unarisen have no arising.
Excluding the arisen and the unarisen, the essence of the arising moment cannot be known, so there is also no arising.
If it is said that the essence of the arising moment is half arisen and half not yet arisen, that is, half arisen and half not yet arisen,
this is also not so. Therefore, the next verse says:
Half arisen and half not yet arisen are not the essence of the arising moment.
Or, the states of already arisen and not yet arisen should also be the arising moment.
The treatise says:
Half arisen and half not yet arisen are not the essence of the arising moment, because half is arisen and half is not yet arisen, like the already arisen and the not yet arisen.

The two states of having already arisen and not yet having arisen are different, just as the two states of having already ceased and not yet having ceased are different. How can you establish that the present moment of arising is the time of arising?

Or else, the states of having already arisen and not yet having arisen should also be collectively referred to as the time of arising, because the two states of having arisen and not yet having arisen are different.

Just as you maintain that half of arising has already arisen and half has not yet arisen, this shows that the state of arising loses its own nature in both the states of having already arisen and not yet having arisen. Therefore arising definitely does not exist.

Isnâ€™t it the case that at the time of arising, it has two characteristics? Half has already arisen and half has not yet arisen. There is one characteristic of having already arisen and one characteristic of not yet having arisen. How can you criticize it by saying that they mutually constitute each other?
When observed separately, the time of arising is different in each case. But when the two characteristics are observed together, how can the time of arising be different?

If you say that at the time of arising, the substance is one but the characteristics are two, and in the states of having already arisen and not yet having arisen, the substance is two and the characteristics are different, then the states of having already arisen and not yet having arisen are different from the time of arising. How can the one substance have two mutually contradictory characteristics?

Since the characteristics are not the same, the substance should be twofold. It is not the case that a single part arises from two parts. Do not contradict the time of arising, with two halves as substance.
If one half has already arisen and is called the time of arising, the other half is not yet arisen and should be called not yet arisen.

Moreover, when half has arisen, the function of arising is already absent. The other half has not yet arisen, and the function of arising is not yet present. How can the two halves be combined to establish the time of arising?

If the time of arising is called the time of arising when the function of arising is absent, the time of non-arising and the time of arising should be called the time of arising. Then one loses the distinction of the three times of one's own school.

Therefore, apart from the two times, there is no separate time of arising. Since the time of arising does not exist, the two times do not exist either. Therefore, all dharmas definitely have no arising.
Next, one should ask the deluded:ğŸ”½Does the self-nature of the time of arising arise from causes and conditions?
Or is it spontaneous?
The first is not so, therefore the next verse says:
If the time of arising is the effect, the substance is not the time of arising.
The treatise says:
If the essence of arising arises from causes and conditions, then it is not the time of arising, because it already has an essence.
Because the future is about to arise, it is called the time of arising. Since the essence of the future does not exist, how can it be called a result?
If it is said that this state is considered in relation to the future, and when it reaches the present it is called a result, then it should be said to be near. How can it be called distant?
In this way, the time of arising is not the time of arising because it is not already arisen, just like the time before it has arisen.
Moreover, this time of arising is included in the distant past, just like the time after it has ceased. How can it be called the time of arising?

If it is said that although the essence of the time of arising does not yet exist, it is already called near because the conditions come together, and since they are both in the future their essences do not exist, then what is the reason for the distinction between the other distant and this near?
This also contradicts your doctrine that the past and future are all distant. Therefore your assertion is just empty words.
The latter is also not so. Therefore the next verse says:
If the time of arising naturally arises, it should lose the nature of the time of arising.
The treatise says:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
If the essence of the present does not arise from causes and conditions, it should be unconditioned and lose the nature of the present.
If that which is not dependently arisen can be called the present, then all unconditioned dharmas should be categorized as the present.
Moreover, that which is not dependently arisen should be like a flower in the sky. Since its essence does not exist, how can it be categorized as the present?
If that which has no essence is called the present, then all non-existents should be categorized as the present.
Therefore, dharmas have no real present.
Furthermore, there are those who say:

If there is no present, then the past and future should also not exist. The present has already passed and has not yet arrived. The two states of past and future are established based on the present. If the present does not exist, the two states also do not exist.
Moreover, the two states should merge, therefore there is an intermediate present.
In order to refute this, the next verse says:ğŸ”½The past is different from the future, and there is a separate intermediate state;
The present is different from the two states, and there should be a separate intermediate.
The treatise says:

If you say that what has already arisen and what has not yet arisen do not coincide, because the state of arising is in the middle, separating the two, if there were no state of arising, the two states would coincide, just as there must be a border between two states, therefore the state of arising must definitely exist. The two states of arising should have a middle, because what has not yet arisen, the state of arising, and what has already arisen are different from each other.
In this way, the middle also has a middle, and it goes on increasing without end, resulting in the fault of infinite regress.
Because of the infinite regress, it is difficult to establish the state of arising.
Moreover, because the categories of what has already arisen and what has not yet arisen are different, like form, sound, etc., there is no separate middle.
Since there is no middle, how can there be a state of arising?
Moreover, if the state of arising is in the future, it is called what has not yet arisen, because it is included in the future.
If it is in the present, it is called what has already arisen, because it is included in the present.
If it is neither present nor future, it is not called the state of arising, like the past, etc.
Therefore, phenomena have no separate state of arising.
Furthermore, if you admit that at the time of arising, the three states of not yet arisen, already arisen, and arising itself are separate,
then upon careful examination, do you abandon the state of arising and attain the state of already arisen?
Or do you not abandon and attain this state?
The first is not so, therefore the next verse says:
If you say that at the time of arising, one abandons and attains the state of already arisen,
Then there should be another state of attainment that can be seen.
The treatise says:

If one abandons the state of arising and attains the state of already arisen, there should be an intermediate state of attainment between the two states of not yet attained and already attained, just like the state of arising.
If you admit this, there will be another state of attainment, and the fault of infinite regress as before will occur at the time of arising.

Because of the fault of infinite regress, it is difficult to establish a state of attainment.ğŸ”½If one abandons the state of arising and attains the state of already arisen, apart from these two states there is no separate state of attainment.
From the state of not yet arisen to the state of already arisen, there should be no separate state of arising apart from the two states.
Also, when one abandons birth, one obtains the state of having already been born. The substance should be different, not one dharma being born.
The latter is also not so. Therefore, the next verse says:
If it reaches the state of having already been born, there must be no time of being born.
If that which has already been born has a time of being born, how does it arise from that?
The treatise says:
That which has already been born and the time of being born must not exist simultaneously, because the time periods are different, just like the past and future.

If that which has already been born has a time of being born, either it should be the same substance or different substances together, then it would not be that which has already been born arising from the time of being born.
Arising from itself is contradicted by what is presently seen in the world.
Coexistence is not a cause, like the two horns of an ox.

If it is said that the same substance has two different aspects and can be said to be a cause without this fault, then the two aspects should not be the same substance in sequence, and the two aspects existing simultaneously should not be cause and effect.
Moreover, if it is the same substance, that which has already been born being born, it should lose its own nature and obtain the nature of another.
The characteristics are not separate from the substance, so they should be the same as the substance.
The substance is not separate from the characteristics, so it should be different from the characteristics.
The substance being the same as the characteristics and different from them cannot be logically so.
The substance and time are not different, therefore it cannot be said that time is different and the dharma is the same.
One dharma at one time having the same and different cannot logically be said to be cause and effect.
From the time of arising until the state of having arisen, there are many fallacies in the investigation of advancing and retreating.
From the time before arising until the time of arising, the examination and questioning should be considered in accordance with reason.
Therefore, the time of arising does not exist separately in reality.
Furthermore, establishing the time of arising as separate from the state of having arisen has no real meaning, but only empty words.
Why is this?
Therefore, the next verse says:
If the time before reaching the state of having arisen is established as the time of arising,
why not say that it is not a pot?
Because the unarisen has no distinction.
The treatise says:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

If you say that the state of arising is not the state of having already arisen, but is called the state of arising because it is about to arrive at that state, then a pot is called already arisen because it has arrived at that state.
But the state of arising has not yet arrived, and therefore the substance of the pot definitely does not exist.
Since the substance of the pot does not exist, what dharma does arising depend on?
You cannot say that a nonexistent dharma is called the state of arising, lest all nonexistents be called the state of arising. Therefore you should call the state of existence the state of arising.

If you say that the substance of the state of arising exists and is not subject to this error, this is also not reasonable, because there is no difference between the state of arising and the state of nonexistence prior to arising, and therefore existence is not established.
If you say that the state of arising is the future because it is the final state and its substance is not completely nonexistent,
this is unreasonable, because it is categorized as future and equal to that which has not yet arisen, and there is no sequence.
If the future is half existent and half nonexistent, and existence is the same as that which has already arisen, then time would be in disorder.
Therefore the state of arising is just an empty word.
Since the state of arising does not exist, arising also does not exist.
Furthermore, if you say that although the substance is not yet complete at the time of arising, the function arises, so it is not completely non-existent.
Non-existence and non-non-existence are not the same as the two states, therefore the dharmas have a separate time of arising.
This is also unreasonable, so the next verse says:
At the time of arising, there is no function, which can distinguish the time before arising;
It is also not the case that the substance is not yet complete, which is separate from the time after arising.
The treatise says:
The two states of no function and function at the time of arising before arising are unreasonable.
If the substance does not exist at the time of arising, the function should not exist.
If the substance exists at the time of arising, it should be already arisen.
Even if it is allowed that at the time of arising there is the ability to give rise to function, but the substance is not yet, it should be called not yet arisen.
The name not yet arisen does not refer to a separate dharma, but only denies what has already arisen and calls it the time before arising.
Since it is called not yet arisen, how can it distinguish that?
If there is a little substance, it should be called already arisen.
Since it is not already arisen, it should have no substance at all.
It is impossible for a single dharma to be partially existent and partially nonexistent, because existence and nonexistence are mutually contradictory and cannot share the same substance.
If you allow that the substance is different, then existence is already arisen and nonexistence is not yet arisen. How can there be arising at the moment of arising?
Therefore, apart from the two states, there is no separate moment of arising.
Moreover, the moment of arising should be the state of already arisen, because it is not nonexistent, just like the moment of already arisen.
In order to illustrate this reason, a verse is spoken:ğŸ”½In the prior state, the moment of arising is nonexistent,
In the subsequent state, it is said to exist.ğŸ”½In addition, it establishes the state of already arisen,
Therefore, this state is not nonexistent.
The treatise says:
The state prior to the commencement of function is called the prior state. In this prior state, there is no moment of arising.
The state in which the function is just commencing is called the subsequent state. In this subsequent state, there is a moment of arising.
This means that the moment of arising is the state of already arisen, because it is different from the prior state, just like the moment of already arisen.
The substance is not completely nonexistent, and can be different from the prior state.
The word â€œalsoâ€ means â€œcompletely.â€
That is, when it has not yet arisen, it is called the state of complete nonexistence. When it arises, it abandons that nonexistence and becomes existent, not nonexistent.
Because of this, it combines with the previous [state of nonexistence] to form the state of having already arisen. If one abandons the state of nonexistence, one must reach a time [when it exists].
Existence is no different from the state of having already arisen. Based on what can one establish a separate state of arising?
Therefore, the state of arising is the state of having already arisen. Because it is not nonexistent, it is like the state of having already arisen.
Moreover, this state of arising should be accepted as having a substance. If it has no substance, the function of arising should be nonexistent.
With both substance and function being nonexistent, how can there be a state of arising?
If there is a state of arising without substance or function, then everything that is nonexistent should all arise suddenly, because nonexistence is no different from this state of arising.
Moreover, if the substance and function of the state of arising do not exist, the combination of causes and conditions should be without effect.
Nonexistent arising exists, as explained above. Therefore, the state of arising is existent, not nonexistent.
That which exists is already arisen, and there is no other state apart from that, therefore it is not appropriate to establish a separate time of arising.
Moreover, one should believe and accept that there is no separate time of arising.
The foolish still stubbornly cling to it, so we briefly investigate further. Is this time of arising existent or nonexistent?
If it exists, it is already arisen. If it does not exist, it has not yet arisen. Apart from this, what is the essence of the state of the time of arising?
To illustrate this principle, we further state a verse:
Sometimes it is called already arisen, sometimes it is called not yet arisen.
Apart from this state of existence and nonexistence, who else would call it the time of arising?
The treatise says:
The nature of the time of arising that is grasped is no more than two kinds when investigated, namely existence and nonexistence.
These two states of existence and nonexistence encompass it. Apart from this, there is no separate intermediate time of arising. For what reason do you unreasonably and falsely grasp it?
This is extremely coarse and shallow, yet you are still confused about it. How much more so the profound and subtle, which you can think and measure!
Therefore, one should believe and accept that there is no separate time of arising.
Since there is no arising at the time of arising, how can there be arising?
Therefore, in reality, all dharmas are without arising.
Since arising is in reality nonexistent, abiding and ceasing are also like this.
Because arising precedes, the meaning of existence is established, and therefore the two characteristics of abiding and ceasing are not separately refuted.

Furthermore, having already extensively refuted the prior existence or nonexistence of the effect, in order to generally and briefly refute the prior existence of the effect, etc., a verse is again spoken at the end of the chapter:
Those who hold that apart from the cause, there is no separate effect that is produced,
The principles of transformation and arising, and transformation and cessation, are all unestablished.
The treatise says:
The SÄá¹ƒkhya school holds that the effect is not separate from the cause.
The effect is the same as the cause, and its substance originally truly exists.
In this way, the substance of the effect is not established as arising or ceasing, because the effect is not separate from the cause, and is the same as the cause in being permanent.

The substance of cause and effect is one, and the principle of distinction does not exist. The nature of all dharmas is always without increase or decrease. This means that what is done is in vain, and if there is even a little activity, it contradicts one's own treatise.
That which cannot be destroyed does not arise. The great elements and so forth would also have no arising or ceasing, because they are by nature like pleasure, pain, and delusion.
Moreover, the great elements should not arise from their own nature, because self cannot arise from self, as this contradicts what is seen in the world.
Then the cause and effect, arising and ceasing, and functioning of all things seen in the world would be nonexistent.
You still slander what is known in the world, let alone being able to believe the profound and hidden meaning.
Thus, observing arising, it does not really exist at all. Because arising is not real, ceasing is also not real. It is only in accordance with the world that arising and ceasing are said to exist.

What is said in accordance with the world is conventional, not true. In the principle of ultimate truth, there is no arising, no ceasing, and the nature of all dharmas is neither annihilated nor eternal.
Since arising and ceasing do not exist, dharmas should be eternally abiding. As extensively refuted above, eternal nature is not real.
If so, there should be no nature of any dharmas.
No, I say that conventional dharmas are not nonexistent.

Don't we in our school speak of a single intrinsic nature? Due to the power of transformation, it does nothing that is not done. Although there is something done, there is no fault of arising and ceasing, of eternalism and nihilism, etc.
Why is this?
When the effect arises, it does not arise, because its nature transforms.
When the effect ceases, it does not cease, because it returns to its original nature.
The nature of the effect is not eternal, because it transforms and ceases before.
The nature of the effect is not annihilated, because it transforms and arises later.
Transformation is not constant, so it is not definitely existent. Intrinsic nature is not altered, so it is not definitely nonexistent.
This is also not so.
Since the principle of the arising and ceasing of dharmas is not established, how can your school's tenet of transformation exist?

Moreover, the words transformation and intrinsic nature, etc., have already been extensively refuted before. It is not appropriate to grasp them again. Therefore what you say is definitely not reasonable.
Some say:

We, the SautrÄntikas, say that effects arise without interval due to the combination of causes and conditions. The arising of effects repays causes and can again give rise to subsequent [effects]. In this way, from beginningless time, causes and effects have been continuously and uninterruptedly connected. There are no faults of arising, cessation, annihilation, or permanence.
Why is this?
Because the continuum is beginningless, there is no arising.
Because the continuum is not exhausted without obtaining an antidote, there is no cessation.
Because the continuum changes, it is not permanent.
Because the continuum is connected, it is not annihilated.
Because it is not a single nature, it also does not transform.
This is also not so.
If there is arising and cessation, then there can be a continuum. Since arising and cessation do not exist, how can there be a continuum?
The meaning of no arising and cessation has already been extensively discussed previously.
If the continuum has an end, then it is annihilated.
If the continuum is beginningless, then it is permanent.
If the substance of the continuum is one, then it transforms.
Therefore, positing a continuum has even more faults.
There are those who say:

We say that all dharmas are always existent. The nature and characteristics of all conditioned [dharmas] have always been real, and they flow through the three time periods in response to the past and giving rise to the future, without the faults of annihilationism or eternalism, arising and ceasing, etc.
Why is this?
Because the substance is always existent, there is no arising and no ceasing.
It is associated with the characteristics of conditioned [dharmas], and therefore it is not eternal;
The arising of the effect responds to the cause, and therefore it is not annihilationism.
Because it is different in each moment, it is not transformation or continuity.
This is also not so.
Because the school of eternal existence has already been refuted earlier.

If the substance of dharmas such as form has always existed, it should be like the unconditioned and apart from the characteristics of conditioned [dharmas], and it would be the same as the SÄá¹ƒkhya [school] that everything is eternal. It cannot be said that the function has arising and ceasing.
The function is not apart from the substance, and it should be the same as the substance being eternal. The substance is not apart from the function, and it should not be eternally existent.
If the function has always existed, it should not be called arising;
If the function has never existed, it should not be able to arise.
The function of production does not yet exist in the future, and that which does not yet exist cannot be called production.
The function of production has already ceased in the present, and that which has ceased cannot be called production.
Apart from these two states, there is no separate time of production. This has been extensively explained before, and therefore it cannot be grasped.
The function of production of dharmas is nonexistent, and cessation also does not exist.

Moreover, if form, etc. are impermanent because they combine with conditioned characteristics, these conditioned characteristics should not be impermanent without combining with other characteristics.
If it is said that these characteristics combine with other characteristics, then this would be an infinite regress.

If it is said that conditioned phenomena have large and small characteristics, and that the mutual characteristics are not an infinite regress, this is also not so. Just as form and other dharmas are not called characteristics because they combine with other characteristics,

production, etc. are also like this. Combining with other characteristics, they should not be characteristics.ğŸ”½Moreover, just as the large characteristics do not take the characterized form, etc. as their characteristics,
the small characteristics are also like this. They should not take the characterized large production, etc. as their characteristics.
If they have characteristics, they would be infinite;
if they have no characteristics, they would be permanent.
The characteristics of the conditioned are definitely not really existent. If they really existed, they would contradict reason.
Why is this?
Like unconditioned dharmas.
The characteristics of the unconditioned are separate from dharmas, and they do not really exist. This should be the same, because they are the same as the three characteristics.
The reality of the unconditioned has already been extensively refuted above.
All conditioned dharmas also do not really exist, because when analyzed by wisdom, they return to emptiness.
Moreover, conditioned dharmas are established in contrast to the unconditioned. Since the unconditioned does not exist, the conditioned also does not exist.

If the conditioned and unconditioned arise from conditions, they are the same as magical creations. If they do not depend on conditions, they are like flowers in the sky. Therefore, one should not grasp them as really existing.
As a scripture says:
The conditioned and unconditioned are all provisionally established by worldly discrimination. Their natures are both empty.
Apart from the conditioned and unconditioned, there are no other dharmas.
Even if it is said to exist, it is just empty talk.
The conditioned and the unconditioned encompass all dharmas. Since these two are empty, all dharmas are empty.
Within emptiness there is absolutely no discrimination or conceptual proliferation. Being empty, unobstructed, and unimpeded is precisely the illumination of the wisdom of the sages.
Therefore a sutra says:
